comment:
Like Sam said “ChatGPT is incredibly limited, but good enough at some things to create a misleading impression of greatness.

It's so hard to listen to. I hate judging people by superficial things and I don't wanna do it. But I wish he'd do something about it. comment:
If there is advice that can be generalized to as many people as possible, it is to understand yourself as deeply as possible. 

Then you will know yourself what your principles are. What your passions and talents are. What is truly important to you and what you should do in life. You won’t be a slave to other peoples opinions, or chasing after meaningless goals like social status or wealth.

author: @jacobijacobi

comment:
The jump from ChatGPT3.5 to 4 was huge in my opinion. It turned from a curious toy into a tool. It's really good at digging up knowledge. You can use it to turn a bullet point argument into an essay. You can use it to extract info from papers, it can code and much more. It feels like you've got a very knowledgeable mentor and powerful workhorse at your side (which does mistakes you still need to pick up). Interacting with it feels like a human - and productive - conversation. I'm convinced ChatGPT5/6 or something similar will  be integrated into the workflow of about every white collar job and I doubt it'll be possible to remain competitive without it in later versions.

The future will be great with AI like this... unless it's our downfall.

author: @thinking-ape6483

comment: For future people coming back to this interview thinking how interesting times 2020's were and how much you would have done if you were born in these times, yes we are here and we can't do much other than marvel and try to keep up at the pace things are moving. I am a very novice ML researcher trying to publish more, but there are a lot of big names and big companies (Google, Cohere, Anthropic, etc) trying to be competitive to OpenAI, however the pace at which these guys are pushing products and updates is unmatched. There are a lot of predictions being made on Twitter everyday saying how these developments will usher a newer era of computing, some even predicting an inflection point in human progress. What unique things OpenAI (+ Microsoft) did (vs say, Google which has an equally intelligent set of people and had a headstart in this domain) and if this is really a new age will only become clear in the hindsight, probably with a lot of case studies published on this. Nonetheless, I want to acknowledge that times are indeed interesting and it is indeed upon people in these times on how we steer this going forward.
author: @yashjakhotiya5808

comment:
1:09:40 "The current worries that I have are that they're going to be disinformation problems, or economic shocks, or something else at a level far beyond anything we're prepared for [...]. And I don't think that gets enough attention". I actually explored this topic further in my latest video "ChatGPT: A Utopian OR Dystopian Future?" where I break down 4 ways AI could benefit us and 4 potential adverse effects of AI on the future of our society. Let's continue the conversation!
Shoutout Lex for being so consistent and surprising us with some of the best guests in very relevant times 💪🏼

author: @historyismetal2187

comment:
There are millions of twiiter AI bots, they follow users based on keywords. For example LGBT, politics, religion

They then learn from replies to the accounts they follow based on questions. For exammple someone tweets "Where do I get the best pizza in Liverpool" and prople repy "Company A" or "Company B" 

It then uses mathematics to llearn specific users personalities and responses. For example people in London normally answer "Why get pizza, pie and mash is better" etc and you can bring terabytes worth of data from milloons of twitter bots over 15 years to build up personalities and responses and create multiple bots

So we have religous, political (letft and right), sport, technology AI bot accounts

The problem with this is that this service is sold commerically, so religous groups for example have swamped twitter with the trans obsesson. Pharma have swamped it with the anti vax obsession to cover the fact a $2 UK vaccine waa banned 2 years ago. Right wing political groups have become dominant, for example trump, walls in US. In the UK Boris Johnson getting votes in northern england, brexit and in both countries nationalism 

The companies/organisations paying all the money to use this technology are not the most ethical

Twitter created the  massive leaps in AI around ineraction ie I am not being rude but a sophisticated chat bot by providing terrabytes worth of data

Its easy to program AI or a chat bot to pass exams, that is a marketing ploy, all you need to do is get the developers to input all possible exam questrions. that is not compex AI, that is very effecive marketing

However what is happening on twitter and has been for 10 years is absolute genui but equally one of the most dangerous things the world has ever seen as 99.99% of people think they are talkiing to a real person

comment:
There comes a point when the rhetoric of psychology becomes more useful in explaining what AI is doing than computer science.

We're talking about a machine which fails terribly at complex mathematics, yet when given access to the ability to use tools, is capable of supplementing itself with the use of a calculator.

We have created a machine, which sometimes needs to use a calculator. I don't think anyone ever imagined such a thing could have ever been possible.
author: @JacenSolo_

comment: Pretty amazing all these technologies, however science is about the truth, and science is always a light in a sea of news and marketing. This paper was published the last year "Some AI Systems May Be Impossible to Compute New research suggests there are limitations to what deep neural networks can do". In my opinion AI capacities are over estimated, simply because any software running on a Turing Machine does computations, but there are limits on what can a,d can't be computed. Can Consciousness be computed? At first what is Consciousness? Can creativity be computed? the sparks of genius displayed by the homo sapiens, can it be computed?
